Numpy for dummies

27 Aug 2017

Python has made itself the default programming language for data science and machine learning. It‚Äôs well documented, simple to use and fun to work with.

But let‚Äôs have a look at what happens when we try to add two lists together‚Ä¶

list = [1,2,3]
list + list

[1,2,3,1,2,3]

Not what we expected. Lists can‚Äôt perform element wise calculations. In fact, it turns out lists in Python have some big limitations which we‚Äôll need to solve if we want to do the kind of heavy maths needed for machine learning.

Enter Numpy. Numpy is a library for Python which adds support for large multidimensional arrays, matrices, and high level mathematical operations on these new datatypes. It‚Äôs fairly intuitive but let‚Äôs take a look at some examples‚Ä¶

Once we‚Äôve imported the library, we can create a numpy array by passing in a regular Python list‚Ä¶

import numpy as np

list = [1,2,3]
np_array = np.array(list)

array([1,2,3])

You‚Äôll see it‚Äôs just like a regular list, but wrapped in this array() object. Now let‚Äôs revisit our first example‚Ä¶

np_array + np_array

array([2,4,6])

Something to note; arrays can only contain a single data type. If we were to put a string as an element, even a single element, the entire array would be converted to strings. The same goes for floats etc. Numpy expects uniformity in our data types.

Onto some more features; we can create a random array using numpy‚Äôs random function, and passing in the dimensions of our array.

a = np.random.rand(3,3)

array([[ 0.63294935,  0.18020465,  0.95212327],
       [ 0.98974435,  0.35659871,  0.86290932],
       [ 0.46544616,  0.51164278,  0.17143704]])

We can check the shape of our array with the np.shape(a) method or just by calling .shape on an existing array‚Ä¶

a.shape

(3,3)

The values returned are the dimensions, starting with the 0th dimension. Most of the time, this will be (rows, columns), although Numpy supports higher dimensional arrays, so it‚Äôs entirely possible to have a shape of (5,5,5,5,5,5,5) or higher, which can be a little confusing to think about.

Accessing attributes is just the same as a list, including the use of the colon to denote all entries in that dimension‚Ä¶

a = np.array([[1,2,3],[4,5,6]])
a[0][1]

2

Let‚Äôs use the colon to select some ranges. Let‚Äôs try all rows, and the middle column (from column 1, up to, but not including, column 2)‚Ä¶

a[:, 1:2]

array([[2],
       [5]])

One common operation in machine learning is reshaping arrays. We‚Äôll look at a common example; flattening an image into a single array. We‚Äôll start with an image measuring 28 pixels by 28 pixels, and having a depth of 3 channels (representing the red, green, and blue channels in a colour image)‚Ä¶

image = np.random.rand(28,28,3)

length  = image.shape[0]
height  = image.shape[1]
depth   = image.shape[2]

flat_image = image.reshape(length * height * depth, 1)
flat_image.shape

(784, 3)

When we have two matrices or arrays of different sizes, for example a 3x3 and a 1x3, numpy will duplicate the smaller array to match the size of the other array. This is called broadcasting and will happen on most element wise operations on matrices of different sizes.

It‚Äôs probably better illustrated rather than coded. You can see how the smaller arrays are copied in grey to make up the empty space and create a compatible matrix‚Ä¶

Another vital operation that is used everywhere in machine learning is the dot product. The dot product is the summation of an element wise multiplication of two matrices. The dot product can be called using np.dot(a, b) where a and b are two matrices of the same size. For arrays of one dimension, the dot product will be a number, but for multidimensional arrays, the result will be a matrix of the same size as the input size‚Ä¶

a = np.random.rand(3,3)
b = np.random.rand(3,3)

np.dot(a, b)

array([[ 0.35544886,  0.43097739,  0.38872774],
       [ 0.73062091,  0.67305096,  0.55726258],
       [ 0.43227186,  0.54603886,  0.46658088]])
üëç
